conclusion: The shadows of all four objects lie below (south of) the objects themselves.
The light source is somewhere above the objects but displaced toward the top of the image (north side).
The instruction says the light is moved forward above the objects, which means toward the bottom (south) of the frame.
Shifting the light southward while keeping its height the same decreases the horizontal distance between the light and each object.
The light rays strike the objects at a steeper (more vertical) angle.
When the incidence angle becomes more vertical, the shadow moves back toward the object (northward in the picture).
When the incidence angle becomes more vertical, the shadow becomes shorter/smaller.
The shadow of the small desk lamp (A) will slide upward and shrink noticeably but will still be recognisable as the ring-like silhouette of the shade.
The shadow of the upright cookie (B) will almost collapse into a darker spot very close to the cookie’s base and travel upward only a short distance.
The shadow of the low cake (C) will retreat just a little and become slightly smaller, ending up almost directly under the plate.
The shadow of the tall sundae glass (D) will shorten the most in absolute terms, pulling markedly upward, but will remain the longest of the four.
After the light has been moved forward, all four shadows lie nearer to their own objects than before and are smaller (shorter).
Ordering by size is preserved (D > A ≈ C > B), but the differences are now less pronounced.

When the light source is pushed forward above the objects, every shadow (A, B, C, D) slides back toward its object and decreases in size, with the tallest object’s shadow (D) shortening the most and the shortest object’s (C) shortening the least, while B collapses almost into a spot and A shrinks to a tighter ring.
